headline: Pasta Flyer, Mark Ladner’s Latest, Opens in Greenwich Village
text: PASTA FLYER When you promise miracles like a good plate of pasta in mere minutes, you have to get it right. That effort is what has taken the chef, Mark Ladner, many more months than he anticipated to engineer his concept. Now, with skills honed in the serious precincts of Del Posto, after time in some of the earthier Batali-Bastianich properties like Otto, he’s ready. Enter the restaurant up some stairs, and you go straight to the counter where the action is. “It’s a completely new design, and it’s much better,” he said. Last spring, poised to open, he and his business partner, Nastassia Lopez, decided their kitchen plan wasn’t working, so they had the whole thing rebuilt to make the pasta assembly line more efficient, always with an eye on the stopwatch. Mr. Ladner’s combination of speed and quality at a low price involves a freezing method. He offers three types of pastas with a basic marinara sauce for $6 to $7; adding pesto or meat costs another dollar, and 50 cents gets you a topping like cheese. Beverages include wine. To one side in the high-ceilinged space are plush banquettes, tables and chairs: 510 Avenue of the Americas (13th Street), no phone, pastaflyer.com.

headline: Review: ‘Frank Serpico’ Updates the Story of the Man Behind a Classic Movie
text: This movie’s intention is in its title. The documentary “Frank Serpico” fills out an American classic that is now almost 45 years old. “Serpico,” the 1973 movie directed by Sidney Lumet and starring Al Pacino, was an adaptation of a book by Peter Maas about a New York City police officer who fought corruption in the ranks and got, among other things, a bullet in the head for his trouble. The real-life subject is now 81 years old, whippet-thin, and a storyteller and self-examiner of no small gifts.

headline: Hilde Lysiak, Reporter, Author, 10-Year-Old

The on-duty officer refuses to divulge any information, but if she’s going to break the story in her newspaper, The Orange Street News, she has to investigate using six basic reporting questions: Who? What? Where? When? Why? How?

headline: A TriBeCa Store With Built-In P.R. Buzz
text: It’s no surprise that fashion boutiques hire publicists, but how many publicists open their own boutique? That’s the back story to 180 the Store in TriBeCa, which was opened by Denise Williamson in the same building, 180 Duane Street, where she runs her fashion P.R. agency, Williamson PR. The idea is to showcase her clients (mostly Japanese labels including Visvim and Nanamica), as well as other brands that she adores. The 2,500-square-foot space is constantly in flux, and is used regularly for events and pop-up installations.

headline: Review: Greta Gerwig’s ‘Lady Bird’ Is Big-Screen Perfection
text: Christine McPherson, who prefers to be called Lady Bird — it’s her given name, she insists, in the sense that “it’s given to me, by me” — is a senior at a Catholic girls’ high school. Sister Sarah Joan (Lois Smith), the principal, has read Lady Bird’s college application essay. “It’s clear how much you love Sacramento,” Sister Sarah remarks. This comes as a surprise, both to Lady Bird and the viewer, who is by now aware of Lady Bird’s frustration with her hometown.

headline: Review: In ‘1945,’ Hungarian Villagers Are Forced to Revisit Wartime Sins

The stationmaster bicycles ahead of them to issue a warning at the watering hole; the residents begin to whisper. It’s the wedding day of the son of the town clerk, who doesn’t want any trouble with elections coming up. The wedding itself seems like a shaky affair, with an uneasy groom and a bride whose previous fiancé is still hovering.

text: I was raised by grandparents who spoke only Mandarin, so I did not speak English until I went to preschool in Philadelphia. There, guided by English-speaking teachers and surrounded by toddlers babbling in loose English, I adopted the new language quickly.

headline: Zad Moultaka’s ‘Sakata’
text: Recorded by the Nederlands Kamerkoor in Utrecht.

headline: Mr Porter’s New Private Label (and Getting Cozy Indoors)
text: Charlie Hedin grew up sailing around Marstrand, a small seaside town in Sweden. So when he developed his textile brand, Tekla, he drew inspiration from the Scandinavian vista: sky blue, ash black, sun-bleached yellow and soft gray.

headline: Evelin Seppar’s ‘Psalm 129’
text: Recorded by the Nederlands Kamerkoor in Utrecht.

headline: In a Superstar Economy, a Bull Market in Superstar Harassers
text: In the recent wave of reports of workplace sexual harassment, a recurring theme stands out: the willingness of companies’ supposed overseers to ignore credible allegations in order to retain a perceived star.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
text: $5.72 MILLION

headline: Letting the Rich Keep Their Tax Benefits
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rock, Reminiscence and Sci-Fi Will Be Part of Under the Radar Festival
text: The Public Theater’s 2018 Under the Radar Festival will feature pieces inspired by the work of the pioneering science fiction writer Octavia Butler and the influential rock critic Lester Bangs, as well as an autobiographical show from the New Yorker writer Adam Gopnik.

headline: Review: ‘The Light of the Moon’ and the Trauma of Rape
text: When we meet Bonnie, a young architect in Brooklyn, she’s on her way to a well-deserved night out. Bonnie drinks and dances, swatting away a few overeager hands. After turning down her friend’s offer to split a cab, she stumbles toward home. Bonnie puts on her headphones, she’s in her own world. And then Bonnie is pulled into an alleyway, where she is brutally raped by a stranger.

headline: Another Venue for Sexual Harassment Claims
text: To the Editor:

headline: Manafort Is the Tip of the Iceberg
text: As a tax professor who specializes in anti-money laundering, what is most striking to me about the criminal indictment against Paul Manafort and Rick Gates is how easy they made it look to launder nearly $20 million dollars from prying government eyes over a period of nearly 10 years.

headline: Netflix Suspends Production of ‘House of Cards’
text: Production on the final season of “House of Cards” was suspended Tuesday, two days after its star, Kevin Spacey, was accused of having made an unwanted sexual advance toward a 14-year-old boy in the 1980s.

headline: June Robles Birt, Whose Abduction at 6 Gripped the Nation, Is Dead at 87
text: By 1934, Tucson figured its Wild West days were behind it. The legendary gunfight at the O.K. Corral, down the road in Tombstone, had occurred fully a half-century before, and Tucson was blooming as a desert mecca for tourists and respiratory patients.

headline: Trump Can Pardon Manafort. He Shouldn’t.
text: The indictments on Monday of the former Trump campaign officials Paul Manafort and Rick Gates have some prominent conservatives openly considering desperate measures. The Wall Street Journal editorial board called on the special counsel whose investigation led to the indictments, Robert Mueller, to resign, arguing that he lacks the “critical distance” to carry out the inquiry. So did the New York Post columnist Michael Goodwin.

headline: The Feminine Mystique
text: A forgotten generation of women artists create work about sex that’s more vital than ever.

headline: The Feminist Pioneers Making Provocative Art About Sex
text: THIS SUMMER IN LOS ANGELES, a hairy, phallic-looking screw painted by Judith Bernstein extended across 180 feet of the exterior of Venus gallery in Boyle Heights. This month at MoMA PS1 in Queens, men and women stripped down to their underwear and rubbed each other with raw fish in a video by Carolee Schneemann. And in London, pink double-headed phalluses bloomed from cacti in Renate Bertlmann’s sculptures at the Frieze art fair.

headline: Lucky Timing for Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke
text: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘The B-Side’ Is an Extraordinary Masterclass in Listening
text: The Wooster Group’s “The B-Side: ‘Negro Folklore From Texas State Prisons,’” first seen at the Performing Garage in Manhattan, is now at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn, where it opened on Friday. A “record album interpretation,” directed by Kate Valk, the production has returned with its original cast of Eric Berryman (who conceived the show), Jasper McGruder and Philip Moore. It runs through March 24. Here is our review from 2017.

headline: Vivian Maier, Through a Clearer Lens
text: No one would find the prospect of posthumous fame more appalling than the photographer Vivian Maier. In life, she fanatically concealed her traces: She liked strong bolts on her doors, fake names (she had at least three in rotation) and what seemed to be a spurious French accent. She rarely discussed or shared her work. Many assumed she was homeless.

headline: Facebook, Paul Manafort, Manus Island: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: Your Grandma’s Favorite Bargain Store Wants You
text: At Next Century, the boutique-minded new shop inside Century 21, Isaac Gindi, a second-generation garmento, and his new hire, Chrissie Miller (native New Yorkers both), were putting the finishing touches on a whole new vision for a metropolitan institution.

headline: Net Neutrality: Why Artists and Activists Can’t Afford to Lose It
text: Somewhere at a comedy club, a new comedian is about to hit the stage for the first time. She will bring with her the modern tool of the trade: her cellphone, equipped with the notes she has typed, a recording app, and five minutes of material that isn’t worth all that technology. This set is going to bomb. Hard. But she will repeat this process — night in, night out, until over time, that five-minute performance becomes tighter and more polished. Eventually, she’ll ask a friend to use a phone to record a set. And that night she will kill. Utterly destroy the room. That will be the first time she uploads footage of herself performing to the internet. Her life will never be the same.

headline: Hear 9 New Psalm Settings for Challenging Times
text: When Lincoln Center first planned the Psalms Experience, an ambitious series of concerts that includes musical settings of all 150 biblical psalms, it was thought of as an antidote to what felt like a terrible year: 2016.

headline: Republicans Delay Releasing Tax Bill, Signaling Trouble for Party
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans delayed the rollout of their tax bill late on Tuesday, in a sign of early trouble for what party leaders had hoped would be a quick victory.

headline: After 25 Years, Michael Tilson Thomas Will Leave San Francisco Symphony
text: Michael Tilson Thomas, whose trailblazing leadership of the San Francisco Symphony spurred American classical music’s westward expansion, announced on Tuesday that he would step down as its music director in 2020, after his 25th season.

headline: Terror Attack Kills 8 and Injures 11 in Manhattan
text: Read the latest on the Manhattan truck attack with our reporting on Wednesday’s developments.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix Australia in November
text: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s TV and movie recommendation site. Sign up for our thrice-weekly newsletter, here.

headline: Aetna Could Offer CVS Valuable Protection
text: Aetna’s third-quarter results show its value to CVS Health. Revenue at the $56 billion health-coverage firm fell 5 percent in the three months to the end of September, partly because it pulled out of health insurance exchanges. But profit jumped 48 percent as the company kept costs under control. That offers alluring protection for CVS, whose pharmacy and drug-benefit business is threatened by rising competition and transparency.

headline: Josh Hutcherson of ‘The Hunger Games’ Keeps His Wardrobe Basic
text: Josh Hutcherson, who has been acting since he was 9, is quite the veteran of sci-fi. At 25, he is perhaps best known for playing Peeta Mellark from “The Hunger Games,” and this month he will starring as a time-traveling janitor in Hulu’s “Future Man.” Off camera, Mr. Hutcherson prefers a more earthbound existence, hanging out in his Los Angeles home in T-shirts, jeans, caps and Adidas Sambas.

headline: He’s George Papadopoulos, Just Not That George Papadopoulos
text: George Papadopoulos is having a rough couple of days.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Why Papadopoulos? Decoding Mueller’s First Legal Moves
text: The New York Times journalists Mark Mazzetti, Matt Apuzzo and Adam Goldman analyze the indictments of Paul Manafort and Richard Gates, and the cooperation of George Papadopoulos with the investigation of Robert S. Mueller III.

headline: Your Favorite Books on Vietnam
text: Last week we asked readers for their favorite books on Vietnam and the Vietnam War. Dozens responded, with suggestions ranging from the well known to the obscure. Below are some of them; to chime in further, click here.

headline: For Philip Murphy, Key Résumé Entries Are Often Left Unspoken
text: The résumé for Philip D. Murphy, the Democratic candidate for governor of New Jersey, features two impressive entries: a 23-year tenure at Goldman Sachs, with high-ranking positions in Frankfurt and Hong Kong, and a four-year tenure under President Barack Obama as ambassador to Germany.

headline: Running One’s Own Path
text: Radio host Peter Sagal and game designer Mike Selinker talk puzzles.

headline: Let’s Hear It for Those With Low Libidos
text: The “Dear Sugars” podcast is an advice program hosted by Steve Almond and Cheryl Strayed. The audio contains more letters; submissions are welcome at dearsugars@nytimes.com. If you’re reading this on desktop, click the play button below to listen. Mobile readers can find “Dear Sugars” on the Podcasts app (iPhone and iPad) or Radio Public (Android and tablet).

headline: Bette Midler, Michael Kors and Eric Schmidt at Hulaween Benefit
text: The annual gala for the New York Restoration Project took place at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine

headline: Connecticut Adopts a Budget After Months of Debate and Delays
text: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut approved a two-year, $40.2 billion budget on Tuesday that includes spending cuts and a variety of measures meant to improve a dire financial situation and end a stalemate that forced the state to operate without a budget for 123 days.

headline: Exxon Will Pay $2.5 Million for Pollution at Gulf Coast Plants
text: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Justice announced Tuesday that Exxon Mobil will pay $2.5 million in fines for flaring gases at eight plants along the Gulf Coast. Agency officials said the announcement was evidence of the Trump administration’s commitment to enforcing the nation’s environmental laws.

headline: Retired Priest, 96, Arraigned on Child Pornography Charges
text: A 96-year-old retired priest who was once a high-ranking official of the Archdiocese of New York was arraigned in State Supreme Court in the Bronx on Tuesday on charges of possessing child pornography. The pictures, which were on his computer, were of girls ages 8 to 14 years old performing sex acts with men or posing naked, the Bronx district attorney said.

headline: A Refusal to Compromise? Civil War Historians Beg to Differ
text: Two months after President Trump stirred fierce debate with a defense of Confederate monuments, his chief of staff, John F. Kelly, has waded back into the fray of Civil War history.

headline: College Application Website Went Down as Deadline Looms
text: For thousands of students anxiously trying to apply to colleges, it must have felt like disaster: Just before midnight on Monday, with barely 48 hours to go before the early deadline at many colleges, the web portal used by more than a million students a year started balking, and then shut down completely.

headline: Red Carpet Looks by Burberry
text: Christopher Bailey’s Burberry designs are a favorite on the red carpet.

headline: Columbia Professor Accused of Sexual Harassment Steps Down
text: A distinguished historian at Columbia University accused this month of kissing and groping a 29-year-old female doctoral student stepped down from teaching and other student-related duties, the university told students and faculty members in an email on Monday.

headline: Mark Halperin’s ‘Game Change’ Partner Says He Was Unaware
text: For the political journalists Mark Halperin and John Heilemann, work on the third installment of their popular “Game Change” book series — set to be an insiders’ account of the final two months of the 2016 presidential race — came to an abrupt halt last Wednesday at around 10 a.m.

headline: James Martin, Who Spurred G.O.P. Gains in the South, Dies at 99
text: James D. Martin, a states’-rights Republican whose squeaker loss in a 1962 race for the United States Senate from Alabama and election to the House two years later helped crack the Democratic Solid South, died on Monday at his home in Gadsden, Ala. He was 99.

headline: De Blasio Donor Says Access to City Hall Didn’t Always Lead to Results
text: A real estate broker and donor to Mayor Bill de Blasio who claimed to have bought favors from city officials conceded during cross-examination on Tuesday that three examples he had initially cited as evidence of his direct line to the mayor had not always resulted in the response he was looking for.

headline: World Series 2017: How the Dodgers Won Game 6, Inning by Inning
text: ■ Follow our live coverage of World Series Game 7 here.

headline: Please Take All Your Belongings
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Trump Plans for Nuclear Arsenal Require $1.2 Trillion, Congressional Review States
text: The price tag of President Trump’s vision of remaking the American nuclear arsenal soared on Tuesday as a new government estimate put the cost of a 30-year makeover at $1.2 trillion, more than 20 percent higher than earlier figures.

headline: Lower Manhattan, White House, Paul Manafort: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Terror Attack in Lower Manhattan: ‘I’m Scared. I’m Scared.’
text: Amateur video appears to show a suspect trying to flee the scene of a deadly vehicle attack near the World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan before being stopped by the police.

headline: From the Archives: The Kidnapping of ‘Little June’
text: June Robles is kidnapped on April 25, 1934, and buried in a metal cage in the Arizona desert. A note is then delivered to her family demanding a ransom of $15,000.

headline: Devils’ Youth Movement Is Off to a Promising Start
text: NEWARK — During the Devils’ game against the Ottawa Senators on Friday, Frank Piserchia wore a red Devils jersey with the number 30 stitched across the front and back. It was a homage to the former goalie Martin Brodeur, the cornerstone on the 1995, 2000 and 2003 Stanley Cup championship teams.

headline: What We Know and Don’t Know About the Manhattan Terror Attack
text: Eight people were killed on Tuesday, and 12 injured when a rented pickup truck plowed down a bike lane that runs along the West Side Highway in Lower Manhattan, officials said. The pickup smashed into a school bus before the driver, Sayfullo Saipov, a New Jersey truck driver who immigrated from Uzbekistan, jumped out and was shot by a police officer, the authorities said.

headline: Mnuchin Talks Taxes and That Vanishing Treasury Study
text: Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, may have spent the last week focused on trying to combat terrorist financing in the Middle East, but overhauling the tax code was never far from his mind.

headline: Ezekiel Elliott Will Serve Suspension After Injunction Is Blocked
text: Dallas Cowboys running back Ezekiel Elliott’s last bid to stave off a six-game suspension was denied on Tuesday when a federal judge in New York declined to block his ban while he appealed the case.

headline: Trump’s Message to Russia About Mueller
text: Paul Manafort, who led President Donald Trump’s campaign during several months in 2016, and Rick Gates, who was also a campaign official, surrendered to federal authorities after being named in an indictment obtained by Robert Mueller III, who was appointed as special counsel in May to investigate connections between the Trump campaign and the Russian government.

headline: Pruitt Bars Some Scientists From Advising E.P.A.
text: WASHINGTON — Scott Pruitt, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, stripped a half-dozen scientists and academics of advisory positions Tuesday and issued new rules barring anyone who receives E.P.A. grant money from serving on panels that counsel the agency on scientific decisions.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Is Gone, and Perhaps the Knicks Don’t Miss Him
text: Go ahead and check the box on the most important metric of the Knicks’ young season and perhaps their entire season: the all-important vision thing.

headline: Signs of Possible Guilty Plea in Turkish Gold Trader Case
text: With just weeks before Reza Zarrab, a Turkish gold trader who has been charged in Manhattan with conspiring to violate the United States sanctions on Iran, is to go on trial, his lawyers have given every indication that he may be prepared to plead guilty.

headline: Slavery Thrived on Compromise, John Kelly
text: In an interview with Laura Ingraham on Fox News last night, the White House chief of staff, John Kelly, said “the lack of an ability to compromise led to the Civil War,” a statement that would shock, among others, the founding fathers. After spirited debates at the 1787 Constitutional Convention, they included Article 1, Section 2, Paragraph 3 in our Constitution, which said each slave, for legislative representation and taxation purposes, counted as three-fifths of a person. That provision is known as the Three-Fifths Compromise, a term that clearly states that Northerners and Southerners were, in fact, quite able to reach weird compromises on slavery.

headline: Let’s Waste College on the Old
text: Usually, when a demographic group is significantly underrepresented on elite college campuses, we consider it a problem. But there is one such problem that almost no one seems to notice or care much about. Nearly 30 percent of college undergraduates are adults, defined by the United States Department of Education as 25 years old or older. But at Stanford, the share of undergraduates who are adults is 1.2 percent; at Yale, 0.7 percent; at Princeton, 0.6 percent; at the University of Chicago, 0.2 percent.

headline: Trail of Terror in the Manhattan Truck Attack
text: A series of diagrams show points where victims were hit during the attack.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What We’re Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

headline: El Museo del Barrio to Close for Several Months During Renovations
text: El Museo del Barrio, the country’s oldest museum devoted to Latino art, announced on Tuesday that it will close its exhibition galleries and theater for several months as part of a planned renovation.

headline: Georgia Tops First College Football Playoff Rankings
text: Defying The Associated Press’s poll and much recent history, the initial College Football Playoff rankings placed the undefeated Georgia Bulldogs (8-0) in the top spot, one above the undefeated Southeastern Conference colossus Alabama (8-0).

headline: Heartburn Drugs Tied to Stomach Cancer Risk
text: People who carry the stomach bacteria known as Helicobacter pylori are at increased risk for ulcers and stomach cancer. But even when antibiotic treatment has eliminated the bacterium, stomach cancer may still arise. A new study suggests that one reason may be the long-term use of proton pump inhibitors, or P.P.I.s, acid-reducing medicines sold under brand names such as Prilosec and Prevacid.

headline: Trump, Niger and Connecting the Dots
text: It is easy to ignore the recent story of four U.S. servicemen killed in Niger, the giant state in central Africa, because the place is so remote and the circumstances still so murky. That would be a mistake. Niger highlights a much larger problem — just how foolish, how flat-out dumb President Trump is behaving.

headline: Glasses Are Cool. Why Aren’t Hearing Aids?
text: If I do my job right, this column might actually change your life. More important, it might change the lives of the people you love.

headline: In Praise of Soccer’s Jack-of-All-Trades, Now Making a Comeback
text: In the year that Bobby Robson coached Barcelona, 1996-97, he was not short of players to praise. His defense was marshaled by Laurent Blanc, his midfield controlled by Pep Guardiola and his attack spearheaded by Ronaldo, the greatest talent of his generation.

headline: The Crucial Role of World Series Losers
text: Baseball is a series of definitive moments, but none are quite like the final out of the World Series. It’s recorded, and we all, players and fans, claim instant perspective. Win the World Series and everything you experienced before it has led, inevitably and majestically, to this moment. Even previous failure has new meaning, and previous success has been bottled. More important, winning made it worth it all, whatever “it” was — the rehab from Tommy John surgery, the 111 losses four years ago, the boos.

headline: Google Docs Glitch That Locked Out Users Underscores Privacy Concerns
text: Google Docs threw some users for a loop on Tuesday when the service suddenly locked them out of their documents for violating Google’s terms of service. The weird part? The documents were innocuous. The alerts were caused by a glitch, but they served as a stark reminder that not much is truly private in the cloud.

headline: Ongoing Trump Migraine: His Initial Foreign Policy Team
text: WASHINGTON — One lasted only 24 days as President Trump’s national security adviser, done in by his lack of candor about conversations he had with the Russian ambassador. Another has been hauled in front of a federal grand jury investigating Russia’s interference in the election.

headline: A Capital Consumed by Talk of Scandal and Suspicion
text: WASHINGTON — The president seethed with resentment, his party ducked for cover and the opposition chortled with glee. Lawyers counseled clients. Lawmakers tried to change the subject. Campaign veterans fretted that colleagues may be wearing a wire. And everyone wondered about a guy named George Papadopoulos.
